editorial_note.title: For the patient reader
editorial_note.body: February is for deliberate reading: shorter days, longer shadows, and books that ask to be lived with, not rushed. This list stays close to the quietly luminous, the reflective, and the book you keep on the table for a week or two.

books.title: The Remains of the Day
books.author: Kazuo Ishiguro
books.why_this_book: A restrained, luminous novel that reveals its depth gradually, ideal for slow, attentive sessions.
books.best_context: Quiet late evenings when the room is still.

books.title: The Housekeeper and the Professor
books.author: Yoko Ogawa
books.why_this_book: A compact, tender novel with a steady rhythm that suits shorter, repeated sittings.
books.best_context: Early mornings or a calm afternoon break.

books.title: Pilgrim at Tinker Creek
books.author: Annie Dillard
books.why_this_book: An exquisite book of attention, best read in small portions that invite pause and reflection.
books.best_context: By a window with natural light.

books.title: The Snow Leopard
books.author: Peter Matthiessen
books.why_this_book: A winter ascent that blends travel, grief, and quiet observation, rewarding steady sessions.
books.best_context: Longer weekend sessions or travel days.

books.title: The Death of Ivan Ilyich
books.author: Leo Tolstoy
books.why_this_book: A brief, profound novella that lingers, suited to one or two deep sittings.
books.best_context: A single focused session in the late evening.

books.title: The Moviegoer
books.author: Walker Percy
books.why_this_book: A quiet, wry novel that explores attention and meaning in everyday life.
books.best_context: Unhurried afternoons when you can linger.

books.title: Nine Stories
books.author: J. D. Salinger
books.why_this_book: Short, precise stories that suit 30â€“60 minute sessions and a measured pace.
books.best_context: Short sessions when you want a complete arc.
